p.seg: In fact, these "heroes" were all about seeking fame, that's what they were! WSM: 。好名，指桀、紂而言。
isn't that acceptable? GX takes this differently: 『正其形而虛其心，言遜而不二。』 WXM: 。端與勉，是存有待之心，尙未通達。

Being full of assertiveness (Yang) and and then making a show of "empty" receptiveness, GX makes it clear that the reference is to ruler of Wèy: 『言衛君康陽之性充張於內，而甚揚於外。」WSM takes 夫 as a pronoun which is grammatically tempting since there otherwise is no subject after 夫: 夫猶彼也。

Listening is limited to the (sound range of) the ear, 俞樾：：『「聽止於耳 ，」當作「耳止於聽。」傳寫誤倒也，乃申說「無聽之以耳」之義。言耳之爲用，止於聽而已 ，故「無聽之以耳」也。WSM agrees on the grounds that Cheng Xuanying's subcommentary apprears to support Yu Yue's emendation:成疏『不著聲塵，止於聽。』是所據 正文本作『耳止於聽。」今本作「聽止於耳。」聽、耳二字互誤也。

TO BE ANALYSED! At the time of emperor Huan (A.D. 147-167) there was an Imperial Secretary who implored somebody else to compose the edicts and to write the reports for him. This person was unable to oblige and said:
A man from Chu was carrying a live pheasant over his shoulder and was asked by a by-passer: "What bird is this?".
A certain Mr. X, a local administrative assistant, was by nature an ignorant man.
When a southerner went to the capital people warned him:
Somebody was having hacked vegetable soup and he was trying some of it with a ladle.
Yao Biao and Zhang Wen were travelling to Wuchang together when near a small Island on the Yangtse river
A poor man from Chu had read the following in the magical book Huainan fang:
In Han times there was an old, childless man,
X and Y had a quarrel
There was a foolish bridegroom whose father-in-law had died,

A Han man went to Wu in the south,

"I paid a visit in the Yamen and was questioned in connection with a murder."
"Why this haste?", he was asked.
After that he never dared to show himself again. It was only after there had been an amnesty that he ventured outside once more.

17Three vulgar fellows wanted to pay a visit of condolence, but none of them knew the ritual rules for this.
In Lu there was a man who wanted to enter a city gate with a long pole.
"It isn't as if I was a sage or anything", said an old man who happened to pass by, "but I have seen a thing or two in my life. Now, why don't you saw this pole in two. You'll get it in that way."
First he carried the pole upright, but it would not go through the gate.
Then he tried carrying it sideways, but it was still impossible to get it in.
He was stuck.
The man from Lu did as he was told.
"It isn't as if I was a sage or anything", said an old man who happened to pass by,
19. A man from Qi, having learnt the lute from a man of Zhao, tuned the instrument and then glued the pegs in place. For three years he did not manage to play a single decent tune.
"Strange!", thought the man of Qi.
When somebody from Zhao came along, our man of Qi asked his expert opinion. The visitor from Zhao soon understood the stupidity that had caused the problem.
